review_title: Not many staff members care as much as they should; doctor overmedicate
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros:
It's a great place to get your feet wet and start in the field. I enjoyed being able to make even the smallest, most miniscule difference in my patient's life just by showing them that someone does care about their opinions, listens to what they have to say and is willing to go above and behind for patients who are high risk, yet are better discharged due to insurance company covers 
You'll meet a variety of beautiful individuals who have their own issues and need help in coping was them due to it affecting their daily lives (this could be extended to some staff members also)
cons: Human Services are racist and biased. The black females hate the whites females and are not afraid of letting it be known whether it's making a scene on the unit or actually talking about you behind your back to patients, dragging them into unnecessary, petty drama. I've unfortunately witnessed several staff members who were drinking while working the evening and night shifts. There were 2 nurses (overnight shift) doing heroin while on the unit and one nurse overdosed. There are no cameras, so staff members have lost their patience (due to being considered on paper as "part time" yet were doing doubles back to back and working over 40+ hours weekly) get a little too rough with the patients and this was never reported, never spoken about /confronted by Head Supervisor and patient was already at a loss because their mental illness was used against them. I've unfortunately witnessed patients who were denied medical care, one woman (frequent flyer) actually had a malignant tumor in her stomach and definitely was not "over exaggerating" her pain. The head doctor/psychiatrist almost killed a patient because he lost (multiple times) in court to have her placed on mandatory medication, so the one time she acted up, he called for the level 3 shots. Her blood pressure dropped so low that she was barely conscious for 2 & 1/2 days. When the supervisors get the heads up that OMH is coming to check in, they have all staff cleaning and checking the charts to make sure there's no errors, etc. Prior to me starting, 3 people had successfully committed suicide and 1 died due to overmedicated by head psychiatrist. I would never suggest or recommend this place if someone really wants to get help.

pros: Great pay and hours. They cared about the employees and changed things to help employee get things done in a fast manner.
cons: Some co-workers are a little lazy and like to procrastinate and some like drama.

review_title: If you need a paycheck work here!

pros: Everything is going So well!

job_title: Clinical Service Representative in West Hartford, CT
pros: Heath insurance, paid vacation time and sick time.
cons: No job growth is available, and is an unorganized company.

pros: I guess I could say that my fellow employees and nurses are very supportive, and I feel grateful to be able to call some of them my friends.  When I finally am able to leave, I can confidently say I'd stay in touch.
cons: Let me put it this way, I've been employed for 6.5 years and have never met or even seen our CEO once.  It's a big place, yeah, but you'd think I'd at least see him walking the halls, right??  I have been introduced from afar to our CNO one time then she even disappeared.  There's no communication to the lesser staff, like us lowly nurses, we were told we're getting uniforms in October (didn't happen), now it's April, but there's been absolutely no communication about it.  We went to every other week paychecks to "save money," and then they cut all overtime and extra time hours as well, but WITHOUT any notice!  So not only do we all have to figure out how to balance out budgets over 2 weeks, we now also don't have any of the extra income we all count on!  So frustrating and disappointing!

pros: Some good coworkers. Women's Auxilary has great gift shop an hosts great vendors. Farmer's Market in the summer.
cons: Pay is very low comparatively. Management is not at all staff oriented. Does not discipline employees who consistently break rules. When staff approach them with concerns about other staff members being unsafe they ignore it in spite of collected evidence. Managers lean on the workers they know will do the work instead of disciplining the workers who do not. Some people get hired who do not speak English and do not have any experience in the department for which they've been hired.

review_title: Senior Management Is Out Of Touch
pros: Co-workers are some of the best I have worked with on our level and below. Very committed to their jobs and patient care.
cons: Senior executives are out for themselves. They will smile to your face and stab you in the back before you completely turn around. They would rather discredit you to make themselves look good. It’s very discouraging.

review_title: Facility has significantly declined in the 2 years I have worked there.
pros: I have thoroughly enjoyed my coworkers and will miss them dearly. Very supportive bedside team.
cons: Their response during and following the COVID surge is overall just sickening. The unending layoffs despite corporate wide bailouts and stimulus money speaks volumes to the hard working front line staff. Over the past 2 years that I have worked here I have seen the culture suffer and I can't name one nurse that isn't disheartened by the constant let down by corporate. The values of the facility have been lost.

pros: I have really enjoyed the years that I have worked at St Francis.  My manager really cares about the nurses.  My coworkers generally work well as a team in caring for patients.
cons: The hospital in general can be "penny wise and pound foolish" when it comes to budget issues, particularly when it comes to supplies and store room issues.  It also seems to take a long time for new evidence-based practice to be implemented.  Travel nurses were not treated well on my unit.
